http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Lacking a large-scale cable laying fleet, the Dutch contracted other nations – any nation but Britain – to help outfit their colonial territories with modern undersea cables. This line, laid in 1913, was completed by the German company Norddeutsche Seekabelwerke.

“The view of the harbor in clear weather is beautiful and animated,” notes an 1897 travel guide to Surabaya. Under Dutch rule since 1743, it was the main commercial port and largest Dutch naval base in the East Indies. “On the water and along the quays great bustle prevails. . . . Chinese and Javanese, Europeans and Arabs, citizens and soldiers mingle” in the crowded streets. The arrival of two Dutch submarine cables in 1913 and 1921 brought the city into further contact with other settlements in the region. But Surabaya’s growth and vibrancy was interrupted by conflict in the 1940s. The city was captured by the Japanese and bombed by Allied forces in the Second World War. And in the 1945 Battle of Surabaya, Indonesian soldiers fought British troops for national independence. This history of profound struggle resonates with the name Surabaya, which some say derives from a mythical battle between two powerful creatures, a “sura” (shark) and a “baya” (crocodile).

An oil boom in the early 1900s transformed Balikpapan from a small fishing village into a center of petroleum production. It became the regional headquarters of the Bataafsche Petroleum Company in 1907, and tankers carrying petrol and paraffin wax soon filled the harbor. Balikpapan’s industrial success spurred investment in roads, buildings, and communications: this included three undersea cables set up by the Dutch East Indies Government and a high-powered wireless telegraph station that could transmit signals hundreds of miles to other colonial settlements. Cable and wireless telegraphy proved invaluable for coordinating petroleum shipping in the area. Oil merchants, explains a 1914 article, “call first at Balikpapan or at some other port in telegraphic communication with Balikpapan so that the latter is always advised by telegraph of the prospective sailings and calls and requirements of these tank boats.”

Menado derives from the word "manadou" or "wanazou," meaning “on the far coast” or “in the distance.” The town is located on the far northwestern tip of the Indonesian island Sulawesi. The Dutch East India Company built a fortress here in 1658 and from that time it was slowly and steadily colonized and Christianized by traders and missionaries. The thick stone walls of the city’s fort still exist, but outside it, the town grew into a colonial village with hedgerows, streets, gardens, and cottages. In 1905, traveling via Menado’s first undersea cable, you traverse a busy port filled with large trading vessels and smaller, slimmer pinisiq, Indonesian sailboats. The beautiful bay actually makes a bad harbor: the reefs and steep slope in the sea floor provide little anchorage. Between the cable landing and the distant mountaintops, expansive coffee plantations dot the landscape. Although it will never grow into a sizeable port city, this location will remain important to the Dutch in part due to its massive coffee exports. 
<!--EndFragment-->

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Portuguese, Spanish, and Dutch forces vied with local rulers for control of this small volcanic island, the northern gateway to the “spice islands” of Maluku and once the world’s only source of cloves. In the 1600s, the Dutch seized Ternate and began to manage trade in the region. The East India Company created a monopoly on cloves by destroying all non-Dutch plantations and making unauthorized growing punishable by death. Trade expansion necessitated faster communication channels, and in 1913 an underwater cable connected Ternate to Dutch settlements in Java and Borneo. As clove production spread elsewhere, the island became less centrally important. But a nearly 400-year-old clove tree—the oldest in the world—still stands on Ternate as evidence of its past distinctiveness.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Across history, there have been three kinds of cable technology: copper telegraph cables, coaxial telephone cables, and fiber-optic internet cables. To create a page for a new cable, see the reference page for cables.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1905, Norddeutsche Seekabelwerke, Dutch East Indies Government

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: After the Boer War, the British government often searched and detained both ships and communications from neutral parties, including the Dutch. This undersea cable, laid on behalf of the Dutch government of the East Indies in 1881, was seen as essential to the the privacy and expediency of colonial communications.

Like so many Indonesian cities, Makassar developed under the influence of European spice trades beginning in the 16th century. The Dutch came in the 17th century and the cables began to arrive in the late 19th century, connecting this city with Bali in 1888, Balikpapan in 1905, and then with Java and Central Sulawesi in 1913. Arriving along the cable at the turn of the twentieth century, you witness the height of Dutch development: they had captured, rebuilt, and renamed the city’s central fort. The new “Fort Rotterdam” looked very much like its namesake, with manicured lawns and large stone buildings with pitched red roofs. The walled city that developed around the fort was a hub for the copra, rattan, pearls, trepang, and sandalwood trade, and enslaved local people for businessmen. Although Joseph Conrad called Makassar “the prettiest and perhaps, cleanest looking of all the towns in the islands,” such beauty reflected colonial interests.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Pipe Networks

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: When they set up their cable station in Cromer, Australia, the PIPE International team decided to take a new approach to the surrounding public. Instead of hiding the network’s development, they started a blog where they posted photos of the cable’s installation, the equipment they used, and the operators’ activities. One engineer recounts that they tried to do community outreach as well. At one point they hosted a barbeque and asked residents to come see why the company had occupied their park for several months. As he described: “a lot of PR went into it to make sure the objections and problems were minimized.” Unlike most fiber-optic systems, PIPE made the cable laying “a social event.” The company's efforts have paid off. Not only did their outreach efforts generate publicity for their network, but they have had few problems with the local community since they began operation.

The Piti cable station, built just down the road from Naval Base Guam, is a fiber-optic superstation. Financed during the cable boom and built in 2002 to land the Tyco Transpacific Network, the building is enormous, though when you enter, the reception desk remains empty, occupied only by a small security camera. You move through a large, hollow room containing rows of empty cubicles, into expansive halls of equipment, and down a cavernous hallway. On one side of the hallway is a giant battery plant in which everything is red; this is the red plant. Round plate batteries are stacked in many rows. On the other side of the hallway is a mirror version of the same plant, but blue; this is the blue plant. The building stands in contrast to the clustered, layered, and remade spaces of Cold War-era cable stations, including Tumon and Tanguisson, further north on the island. There are no photos on the wall, or anything to mark that you are on Guam. The station has been meticulously designed, completely redundant, and has more than enough power and space to land several other systems. The station, like many others, had been overbuilt in anticipation of future growth. Afterward, the market crashed and no networks landed here until 2009. There is plenty of extra room to offer to other cable networks, data or call centers, and digital content companies.

The PPC-1 cable, laid in 2009 to connect Australia, Guam, and Papua New Guinea, has enough capacity to carry simultaneous phone calls from the entire population of Australia – over twenty million people. Countries don't need to have an extensive network in part due to the enormous capacity of fiber optics.

The IOCOM was inaugurated in India in 1981 with a commemorative stamp to mark the occasion. “From time immemorial men have sailed the lonely seas," one description of the system reads, and the "seven Commonwealth Countries of India, Shri Lanka, Malaysia, Singapore, Hong Kong, Australia and Canada joined hands to lay the cable system across the Indian Ocean between Madras and Penang."

The Kuala Muda station in Penang, commissioned in the early 1980s by Telekom Malaysia (TM), was the country’s first landing site for underwater telephone cables. As the westernmost point on the Malay Peninsula, the state of Penang made a logical terminus for the Indian Ocean Commonwealth (IOCOM) cable from Chennai, completed in 1981. While Penang’s nineteenth-century telegraph connections surfaced in the bustling heart of colonial George Town, IOCOM and subsequent cables landed ten miles north in a comparably remote area where the Muda River flows into the Malacca Strait. By placing the station on the outskirts, TM minimized the risk of cable damage from anchors and trawls of passing ships. Today, the company controls all four of Malaysia’s cable hubs (and five smaller stations), similarly positioned in fishing villages and beach towns on the urban fringe.

In 1902, as part of a wave of strategically and nationally driven cables in the early twentieth century, the French post and telegraph service laid a system between Tourane, in French Indochina, to Amoy, China.

“CABLE SITUATION AT AMOY. MUCH DISCONTENT” reads the headline in a 1931 Singapore newspaper. “The prosperity of business in Amoy largely depends upon its rapid communications by cable to the South Seas,” the article explains, but telegrams “intended for Amoy are now relayed to Shanghai.” Service was disrupted when, a few days prior, Chinese officials shut down the Great Northern Telegraph Company office on Kulangsu Island, where a Danish cable stopped on its way from Hong Kong and Shanghai. This cable originally bypassed Amoy, but in 1873, the company added a branch to the city without Chinese permission and began profiting from the added traffic. When China took control of the Kulangsu-Amoy connection in 1931, it disrupted local businesses already heavily reliant on submarine telegraphy.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Đà Nẵng is a city divided by a river. Before the first bridge was built in 2000, residents had to take a ferry between the eastern shore, the site of the former French colonial settlement, and the western peninsula, which shelters the city from the sea. The peninsula was once home to poor fishermen, but many have since moved away as beach resorts populated the coast – these extend south several kilometers to the site of Đà Nẵng’s international cable station. Like Vung Tau to the south, Đà Nẵng had long been connected to undersea networks, first as part of the French colonial cable system and later as part of the Americans' wartime communications strategy. Đà Nẵng’s international cable station, however, was the first built with the support of the national telecommunications carrier, Vietnam Posts and Telecommunications. While the city's infrastructures, from bridges to cable systems, bring connections, they also bring the expansion of capitalism, providing benefits to some at the expense of others.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1990-2003 (AtlanticCable.com says landed at Cape D' Aguilar; Subsea Book says Deep Water Bay)

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This 735km cable has connected Hong Kong and Taiwan since 1990. However, its low capacity of 420 MB/s and the bursting of the telecommunications bubble in 2001 meant that it was decommissioned long before it was technically obsolete.

For decades, Taiwan’s cables have been concentrated at its northern and southern tips. While the Tanshui and Toucheng stations are on the fringes of Taipei, the Chunghwa Telecom station is located in the rural southern township of Fangshan. Most traffic to Southeast Asia, whether from Taiwan, East Asia, or North America, passes through the Bashi Strait, the narrow passage separating Taiwan and the Philippines. Fangshan was the ideal gateway to this route until recently, when a spate of natural disasters severed numerous cable links. An earthquake in September 1999 broke Taiwan’s terrestrial backbone, one undersea cable, and caused cell sites and radio relays to collapse. During the 2006 Hengchun earthquake, submarine landslides took out nine undersea links. Most recently, Typhoon Morakot disrupted six international cables and 1,700 wireless base stations, in addition to taking 500 lives. Fangshan, perched on the edge of the Bashi Strait, is no longer a popular interconnection point for undersea traffic.

No one is allowed past the gate to Cape D’Aguilar, except those with permission. At the southeast edge of Hong Kong Island, the cape’s high hills formed a perfect location for a radio station, once Hong Kong’s major high-frequency transmission center. From here, signals broadcast past the nearby mountains and out onto the ocean, where fishermen benefit from regular weather updates. When an old building nearby was retrofitted as a cable landing station, these radio signals became a problem. The high-powered wireless threatened to damage the building’s electronics equipment. The station had to be completely protected and insulation was placed throughout its interior. As a result, the cable station is a completely wireless-free zone: not even mobile phones will work inside.

Fiber-optic cables encode signals in light and send them down a thread of glass. Although in development since the early 1980s, the conservative cable industry did not lay the first transoceanic network until 1986. The immense capacity of fiber-optics have made possible the Internet as we know it today.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1900-?; German PTT             Sherard Osborn           2 cables laid over this route. CS Von Podbielski loaded the cable aboard at Rotterdam. Opened for traffic on the 4th October 1900 (See AtlanticCable.com)

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Danish ship CS Sherard Osborn, on behalf of Administration of Posts of the German Empire, laid German-manufactured cables from the free port of Tsingtau to both Tschifu and Shanghai in 1900. In the process Tsingtau was connected to the Great Northern Telegraph network, and the German telegraph service took an important step towards completing its global cable loop.

Tschifu is today called Yantai, meaning “smoky tower.” In a way, this harbor town was always a critical communications node: the name refers back to the Ming Dynasty, when locals would light smoky fires to warn the village of approaching Japanese pirates. On the northeastern tip of the Shandong Peninsula, Tschifu was directly south of Dairen, due west of Seoul, and straight north from Shanghai. Its central location made it an ideal cable hub during the telegraph era. In the first decade of the twentieth century, ten cables were landed here, primarily by the British and the Germans, connecting to Tsingtau, Port Arthur, Taku, Dairen, Shanghai, and Wei-hai-wei. Even before the cables were landed, the city had long been an important traffic hub: it had been an international trading port for almost half a century and the home to embassies of seventeen nations.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: When China began to struggle against imperialism in the late 1800s, Qingdao was an important node of resistance. The Boxers, an anti-imperialist, proto-nationalist Chinese movement, had a strong presence in area, and in 1897, the Chinese government began building up a military base here to protect against foreign invasion. Shortly thereafter, German troops seized and occupied this fort. After a year of fighting, China conceded the area to Germany, who re-named the city Tsingtau, a French transliteration of the original name. This small Chinese fishing village was transformed into a German administrative and economic center, with tall three-story stone buildings, wide streets, electricity, and a navy base. At the turn of the century, two telegraph cables were landed, one connecting to Tschifu and one to Shanghai. Today, two major cable systems continue to land at Qingdao, linking the city to Korea and across the sea to California.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This final link extended the Commercial Pacific Cable Company's network from Manila to Shanghai in 1906. On July 4th, United States President Theodore Roosevelt and the president of the Commercial Pacific Cable Company, Clarence Mackay, exchanged messages that telegraphically encircled the globe.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Pratt and Roosevelt. “Developments in the Field of Cable and Radio Telegraph Communications." AIEE Technical Paper (May 1944), 3.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: As a key British treaty port in the wake of the first Opium War, Shanghai rapidly developed as a contact zone for international powers. The city brought together a mix of cultures, architectural styles, and social classes, but these connections were made possible by the exploitation of Chinese labor and a concession system that granted foreigners immunity to Chinese law. The first telegraph cable arrived in 1871, covertly brought ashore in the middle of the night by the Great Northern Telegraph Company. In the ensuing years more cables were laid without official Chinese sanction. Without the cooperation of the Chinese people, however, cables remained vulnerable to disruption. Enterprising pirates stripped cables for resale. Local villagers ripped down lines that disturbed ancestral grave sites and the landscape’s feng shui. Men armed with rifles had to patrol the Yangtze River to stop sailors from throwing anchor and severing the cable. The situation was ameliorated by degrees when, in 1875, the Chinese government offered official recognition and protection to the cables in exchange for ownership of the illegal lines upstream of Shanghai. A period of relative stability followed, as China slowly developed an overland monopoly on telegraph lines while colonial powers built ever more underwater connections.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: When the Spanish took possession of Manila in the sixteenth century, they brought galleon trade ships, Christian missionaries, and tobacco seeds. They also brought the "polo y servicio," a practice of forced labor in which indigenous Filipinos were put to work on colonial infrastructure and agriculture. By the late 19th century, Manila’s streets were host to both a growing commercial sector and a deep-seated resentment that eventually erupted into guerilla resistance. In 1880, a cable was laid to Hong Kong to Bolinao, extending arduously overland to the capital city. By the time the Manila cable station finally opened for service in 1887, the Philippine Revolution was in full swing. The link was repeatedly cut by revolutionary forces and within a year it was replaced by a submarine cable to Manila Bay. Yet even that cable was not safe from strife – the Spanish-American War started in 1898, bringing about further conflict and cable disruption. When the United States finally replaced Spain as the colonial force in the region, they turned to secure their new territory from the indigenous resistance, leaving up to one million Filipino casualties. Eager to solidify their power in the Philippines, the Americans laid another cable, connecting Manila to the United States via Guam and Honolulu. In the years that followed, they used telegraph networks to surveil Filipino leaders and safeguard their empire.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Growing in importance following the Boxer Rebellion, the German cable system in China sought to maintain its impressive international network and to profit from the growing international need for communications. In the process, Tsingtau “has been converted into a charming town of officalism,” notes the Japan Weekly Mail, who did not shy from expressing its own colonial interests in the region.

As part of a growing desire for greater sovereignty over its telecommunications network, Japan laid the majority of this cable in 1908, linking the nation to Manchurian China. This extended their communications network well into Chinese territory, and picked up where Russian influence had been waning in the wake of the Russo-Japanese War.

Dairen, Manchuria is today’s Dalian, China. This port city sits on a peninsula that juts out into the Yellow Sea, bisecting the Chinese mainland and North Korea, and threading together the region’s histories of communications and transport. At the time of its first cable landing, this piece of land was under Russian control. When war with Japan broke out in 1904, the Japanese quickly took control of Dairen and brought in their own telegraph cables. In the years that followed, the war-ravaged city was rebuilt as a "modern colonial showcase" by its new rulers. Extensive planning went into Dairen's green spaces: parks, shaded avenues, and thousands of Acacia trees transformed what many had thought of as a "shabby port town" into a "beacon of civilization." As part of the effort to clean up Dairen, planners segregated neighborhoods, keeping the thousands of migrant Chinese workers apart from Japanese residents. And, in tune with other infrastructure developments, new broadcasting facilities were established to spread Japanese culture and propaganda across the airwaves.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This cable, laid by the British Eastern Extension Australasia China Telegraph Co. in 1884, connected British Hong Kong and Portuguese Macau. The Portuguese government paid Britain a yearly subsidy of £500 for the service. Although China never signed the Convention for the Protection of Submarine Telegraph Cables negotiated that year, its protections were nevertheless afforded to the Hong Kong – Macau line, thanks to the exceptional status of the colonial territories.

Along the shores of the Pearl River, across from Hong Kong, Macau was a fishing village until Portuguese traders, seeking a place to dry and store goods, established themselves there in the mid-16th century. Commodities were not the only things traded: in the same period Macau was a key node in the trafficking of Chinese slaves to Portugal. Even after the enslavement of the Chinese was outlawed, slavery remained an ever-present part of social life. In the early 1600s, there were approximately 6 slaves, the majority of whom had been brought from Africa, for every Portuguese family. Portuguese shacks grew only gradually into a settlement, and it was not until after the opium wars of the 19th century that China ceded the right of governance and occupation in exchange for a promise that Portugal would assist in levying a tax on the drug. Only a few years before, in 1884, a telegraph cable linked Macau to Hong Kong, across the bay. The island remained under Portuguese control until 1999, making it the last remaining European colony in Asia. That year, it was both transferred back to China, and linked via a modern undersea cable system, SEA-WE-ME-3, which revived the earlier connection to Hong Kong.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: Telegraph Bay, Pok Fu Lam, Hong Kong

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Barty-King: from here they connected to Eastern Extension office at Marine Hour – on the site occupied by Old Mercury House in 1979.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In nineteenth-century Hong Kong, a barrage of undersea cables – from Singapore, Shanghai, Fuzhou, Manila, Labuan, and Macau – landed at Telegraph Bay. From here, cables wound inland across the island’s northern shore, through the city center to the busy Eastern Extension cable office. The daily work of cablemen at “Electra House,” as it was called, was eventful. Traffic was re-directed from one network to another, messages linked local commerce into a global economy, and important political information was relayed about British-Chinese relations. Yet as they sustained the network, cablemen also worried about sustaining themselves. They were concerned about finding healthy food (one worried that local vegetables were not clean enough to eat) and about catching the plague (another remarked that “Hong Kong would not be Hong Kong if we didn’t have an epidemic of something every year”). And leading up to World War II, a cableman recounted, “Life in Hong Kong has been subject to rude jolts during recent years… we had quite a few delightful moments dealing with traffic which poured in for places which had been 'interrupted by bomb.'” Not long after, station life would be interrupted completely when the Japanese took over the island. Today the work of Hong Kong’s cablemen has moved to the island’s southern shore, but Telegraph Bay remains a center of information exchange. It is now the location of the expansive Cyberport, a “creative digital community” built to foster technology development.

Submarine cables are usually laid, initiated, and then forgotten. Inaugurated in 1870, the Penang-Singapore line was hailed for bringing the East “into intimate connection with the living world of Western intellect and science.” Three years later, however, it was back in the news for something much more spectacular: a large tooth from a mysterious deep-sea creature was found wedged into the faulty cable line.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Was located at 44 Northam Road, now Jalan Sultan Ahmad Shah.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In George Town at the turn of the 19th century you witness the beginnings of a modern city. The streets are lined with warehouses and ghauts, wide steps leading from the street to the water. Banks, trading areas, and emporium stores are beginning to appear along Beach Street. Since its founding by the British East India Company in 1786, the town has grown into a bustling trading port and commercial center. George Town has been built on water: its commercial center stands on a swampy wetland that was leveled and filled in the early 1800s. English settlers built their bungalows high up on top of Penang Hill, forbidding natives to do the same. The settlers’ wealthy Chinese business partners were allowed to build in the middle part of the hill. The cable – part of the emerging modern city – surfaces close to the water, but ultimately connected those who lived far above it.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1845-1900,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 22, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1850.htm.
Visions of Penang Archives Online (My Heritage My Penang), accessed June 22, 2013, http://www.visionsofpenang.com.my

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: A trading post since the second century, the island of Singapore was a hub of exchange for Southeast Asia long before the British settled there in 1819. When the first underwater telegraph cable arrived forty years later, Singapore was a bustling port city, what one nineteenth-century cable survey called “that thriving halfway house between Europe and the East.” Although produced in a factory in London more than six thousand miles away, the Singapore-Muntok cable was insulated with the coagulated sap of trees native to the region. The Malays had used this substance, known as gutta-percha, for generations to make whips and other products. In the 1840s, a Scottish doctor stationed in Singapore took notice of the sap and brought it back to London. Gutta-percha made an ideal electrical insulator and became the material of choice in the cable industry.  By the time gutta-percha-encased wires populated Singapore's waters, demand had all but wiped out the local flora that made its transmissions possible.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value:
Selected sources:
Ken Beauchamp, History of Telegraphy (IEE History of Technology Series). London: The Institution of Engineering and Technology, 2001. 135-8.
Chester G. Hearn, Circuits in the Sea: The Men, the Ships, and the Atlantic Cable. Westport, CT: Praeger Publishers, 2004. 10-11.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This cable, laid under the direction of Danish engineer Emanuel Hansen, completed the first electric link between Taiwan and China. In China, it was landed at the mouth of the Min River, in Foochow in 1888.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Jonathan Manthorpe, Forbidden Nation: A History of Taiwan (New York: Palgrave Macmillan, 2005), 147.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Midway between Taiwan and China, this chain of small islands is strategically important. As a result, even though they are sparsely populated, the Penghu Islands have long been linked to communications networks. In the late 1880s, at the order of the Qing governor of Taiwan, a telegraph cable connected Penghu to China in the east and Taiwan to the west. This was accompanied by gun emplacements meant to fortify the “militarily indispensible” island. Despite these measures, less than ten years later the islands were ceded to Japan along with Taiwan, a result of China’s defeat in the Sino-Japanese war. The Japanese would remain in Penghu throughout the first half of the twentieth century, laying cables that linked across the Taiwan Strait. While the connected cities grew busy with international trade, the Penghu Islands remained apart from the action, with most ships and signal traffic merely passing through. Today, the islands are linked to the rest of Taiwan via another kind of subsea technology: major undersea power cables link Penghu into Taiwan’s electric grid.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1901-1950,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed August 19, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1901.htm.
Jonathan Manthorpe, Forbidden Nation: A History of Taiwan (New York: Palgrave MacMillan, 2009), 147.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In the 10th century, tall pagodas were erected to protect Fuzhou from the “evil influences of atmospheric currents.” These currents brought more human trouble than atmospheric calamity, however, as Fuzhou proved to be a critical site in the contestation and violent defense of British opium sales. After taking China to war in order to secure their access to regional markets, Britain opened the port, then called Foochow, to foreign contact and trade for the first time in centuries. Tea was exported from the country through Fuzhou in massive quantities while European technologies and opiates alike crossed its shores. More recently, the area has been opened to foreign circulations in other ways. As fiber-optics replace the colonial cables laid in its harbor, the Chinese government has iteratively marked parts of Fuzhou as industrial free trade zones, opening its borders to foreign investment without taxation. As a part of the “Maritime Silk Road” the port presently hosts operations from 93 of the global Fortune 500 companies.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Ben Ross, “Coming to America…Fuzhou’s Main Export is People,” Urban Sociology and Urbanism, in China and North America, accessed September 12, 2013, http://benross.net/wordpress/illegal-immigration/2007/05/22/.

Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1845-1900,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed September 9, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1850.htm.
Rev. Stephen Livingstone Baldwin, “A Trip to China,” Frank Leslie’s Popular Monthly xviii (July-December, 1884), accessed September 9, 2013, http://www.gnudoyng.net/christianity/1884_foo-chow.php.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1917, the Japanese Government extended a second link from Nagasaki to Taiwan.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: On AtlanticCable.com, many landings indicated by "Mogi, Nagasaki-ken, Japan"

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Like many port cities in Asia, Nagasaki was “discovered” by imperial powers – in this case, the Portuguese – and developed for trade. In the nineteenth century, Nagasaki became a busy transit point, with a vibrant ship-building industry, an anchorage site for the Japanese navy, and a telegraph cable landing point. Three years after its first submarine telegraph cable was landed in 1871, the telegraph company established a headquarters here, in a large two-story office building abutting the harbor. Within a few years, Japan would build up its internal landlines, and the country would be connected to the rest of the world via Nagasaki. The importance of this station was clear to Japan and its enemies. Described as “clutching the aeortic artery of international communications in Japan,” Nagasaki, as a hub and military harbor, was also a target. The cable to Vladivostok was taken out of service during the Russo-Japanese War, but the city remained undamaged. During World War II, however, Nagasaki was hit with the atomic bomb, the second and last to ever be deployed, killing several hundred thousand people. After the Japanese surrender, the city would slowly rebuild. Old communications lines were taken out of service, and new coaxial cables laid in their place.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1901-1950,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed August 10, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1901.htm.

“The Great Northern Telegraph Company Centenary Book,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed August 10, 2013, http://www.atlantic-cable.com/Books/GNT/.
“Umegasaki Stories,” Nagasaki: People, Places and Scenes of the Nagasaki Foreign Settlement 1859-1941, accessed August 10, 2013, http://www.nfs.nias.ac.jp/page007.html.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: You make your way through sludge and silt to come ashore – quite a different experience from the clear seawater of the southern Japanese islands. A Spanish and then Dutch colony in the seventeenth century, Tanshui (also known as Dansheui) grew to become the largest port in Taiwan by the late 1800s. Coal and tea were exported in vast quantities from the natural harbor where the Tanshui River meets the Strait of Taiwan. In 1887, an underwater telegraph cable joined the bustling city to Fuzhou on the Chinese mainland, and a year later the Taipei Telegraph Academy opened nearby. But in the early twentieth century, the buildup of silt at the river mouth caused much of the shipping traffic to move east to Keelung. While its port status dwindled, Tanshui retained its position as an international cable hub. Several fiber-optic systems arrived in the early 2000s, linking the town to points throughout East Asia and the Pacific. Twin landing stations, owned by competing telecom carriers, are situated along a quiet beach west of the city, famous for vivid sunsets and a popular leisure destination for residents of Taipei.

Dutch 19th century telecommunications interests, motivated by a growing antipathy to the English, soon found an ally in France. The expansion of the East Indies network continued in 1905 with partial French financing of a connection between Batavia, Billiton, and Pontianak.

You arrive at the “Amsterdam of the tropics,” or so the Dutch East India Company imagined it when they built up Jakarta to support the spice trade. Streets and canals are named after Dutch provinces and cities, and the city is named Batavia, after Dutch tribal ancestors. The oldest part of the town, built near the coast and surrounded by walls, is the hub of a far-flung trade network. To the south, Weltevreden is ordered, regulated, and home to shops and government offices. Through and through, the colonial landscape is structured to facilitate the smooth flows of trade. Yet it is also designed to separate colonists from the Javanese. When the first undersea cable was landed in 1859, the telegraph station molded to the city’s organization. The “cable colony” is now “one of the favourite stations in the Extension Co.” – it has a rambling garden, tennis courts, stables, a reading room, and a broad entryway flanked by palm trees. As is true in the rest of Jakarta, the station’s non-European laborers are excluded from the extravagant lifestyle of the cablemen, relegated instead to neighborhoods “in and around the European city.”

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, "Cable Timeline: 1845-1900," History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 29, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1850.htm.
“Batavia: The Exiles' Mess,” The Zodiac, 1922. Held in the Cable & Wireless Archives.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The island of Billiton (the old Dutch spelling of Belitung) was a valuable site of tin extraction in the colonial era. Dutch mining operations started in the mid-1800s with the formation of the Billiton Company, named after the island. The company imported thousands of Chinese indentured laborers to perform the heavy and dangerous work in the mines. In the early 1900s, the Dutch East Indies government brought two submarine cables to Billiton’s capital city of Tanjung Pandan, connecting it to colonies in Java, Borneo, and Sumatra. Only a decade later, however, the capital was looted and set ablaze in a worker’s revolt. Belitung and the neighboring island of Bangka are still key points in the global tin trade. The Guardian estimates that in 2012 they produced 90% of the tin in Indonesia, an extraordinary amount given that Indonesia is the second-largest producer of the metal in the world. Environmental advocates recently launched a campaign against Microsoft, a company that uses tin in the production of electronics, accusing them of ignoring the ecological impacts of mining on the island.

On a desolate road in Western Borneo, you hear dogs whining and the cry of a newborn child. Watch out, the Malaysians would tell you, this is the pontianak, the vampiric ghost of a mother who died in childbirth. According to local legend, when Arab adventurer Syarif Abdurrahman Alkadrie ignored indigenous warnings and settled here in 1771, he was haunted by the pontianak. Undeterred, he established a Sultanate, and built a mosque, a fort, and a coastal trading station amidst the swamplands. Chinese immigrants transited through Pontianak, and some settled, trading gold mined from Borneo’s mountains. The Arab ruler also welcomed the Dutch, setting the stage for colonial expansion in the region. Even after Pontianak became a protectorate of the Dutch East Indies, it remained a place of encounter and conflict between these diverse ethnic groups. At the turn of the 20th century, the Dutch allied with another colonial power, the French, to make Pontianak a connecting point between cables to Batavia and French Indochina. Unlike the city's varied inhabitants, these links did not have such long lasting effects. It was not until a century later, in 2006, that the next cable landed here, a fiber-optic one linking out to Batam and Jakarta.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1901-1950,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed September 8, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1901.htm.

Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 2001-,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed September 8, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index2001.htm.

Bill Glover, “French PPT,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed September 8, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/CableCos/France/ptt.htm.
“Sultanate of Pontianak,” World History at KMLA, accessed September 8, 2013, http://www.zum.de/whkmla/region/seasia/xpontianak.html.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Tanguisson Beach station, built to house American networks during the Cold War era, resembles an underground bunker. Entering, you descend several stories down a fortified stairwell and even then, can only access the equipment room once admitted through a secure metal door. Immediately inside the entrance is a decontamination chamber, a former precaution for nuclear attack, and now a storage closet. Everything inside is redundant in case the domestic infrastructure fails. Multiple, completely separated generators comprise backups for building power and air-conditioning units. Independent battery plants sustain the equipment. During the coaxial era, Tanguisson was staffed by at least two employees at all times, but was often occupied by many more. On the wall, you witness evidence of the community formed here: yearbook-style photos of all of the AT&T stations in the Pacific, including Makaha, Keawa‘ula, Bandon, San Luis Obispo, and Point Arena. Each has an image of the station and photos of the people who worked there, with their name and position listed underneath, grouped as a school class would be. Photographs of the cable ships, AT&T cable landings, and maps of Guam decorate the walls. Due to the massive downsizings that have occurred since the 1980s, far fewer people work at Tanguisson today. The cable community, however, still exists.

You are carried to Baler’s shores with nine-foot waves surging overhead, curling in on themselves and frothing as they meet the warm, sandy beach. This coastal town was once entirely decimated by the “tromba marina,” a tsunami wave that inundated the area in 1735. The surf still looms large in people’s minds. Locals claim that at times they hear it as far away as the provincial capitol building, almost a mile inland. Even beyond the city, Baler’s surf is more famous than its land. Between October and March, when the waves are the largest, the ocean teems with bodies and boards. Like the town’s sole undersea cable, surfing came to Baler because of global media flows. A little over a decade after the transpacific telephone cable arrived, a scene from the film Apocalypse Now was shot on Baler’s beaches. In it, a surf-crazed colonel pushes his troops to ride the waves amidst enemy gunfire. A recreated Vietnamese village was blown up and the trees along the shore were burned. After filming, the crew left behind their surfboards and a new sport.

Completed in 1964, Trans-Pacific Cable 1 was the first coaxial cable to link Japan and the U.S. via landing sites in Guam and Hawai'i. It was also part of a global communications network that linked tracking stations, command centers, and other infrastructure during the Apollo missions, including the moon landing in 1969. TPC-1 carried voice signals across the ocean for twenty-six years and, since 1990, the decommissioned cable has been used to study earthquakes.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1901-1966; Telcon; Eastern Extension Australasia & China Telegraph Co; Anglia (see AtlanticCable.com)

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This line, a diverse pathway to Australia, was strung across the Indian Ocean in 1901. As a strategic asset during times of conflict, the Cocos cable station attracted armed aggression from the Germans in WWI and the Japanese during WWII, both of whom sought to fracture communications between colonial territories.

Typhoons and loneliness were the greatest perils for the cablemen working on the Cocos Islands in the early and middle twentieth century. Like Midway Island, the Cocos were largely uninhabited before the establishment of a cable station in 1901. The station was built at the highest point on the island: two meters above the high water mark, but this didn't keep it from damage during cyclones in 1907, 1911, and 1933. These caused flooding, collapsed palm trees onto the cable station houses, and wreaked havoc for international communications. During quieter moments, cablemen played tennis, staged theatrical performances, and waited eagerly for the arrival of supply ships every three months to bring food, mail, and mild excitement. Today, tourists seek out the Cocos for their quietude and isolation, sparsely and silently scattering themselves across the white beaches and blue-green waters. Floating just above the ocean’s surface, with no hills or mountains, these low-lying islands will face flooding in the coming years as climate change brings ashore ever-more intense storms.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: ￼Margaret Miller, Gentlemen of the Cable Service: A Pictorial History of Australia’s Overseas ￼Cable Telecommunications Service, 1870-1934 (Sydney: OTC Australia and Publimedia, 1992), 10.
￼Margaret Miller, Gentlemen of the Cable Service: A Pictorial History of Australia’s Overseas ￼Cable Telecommunications Service, 1870-1934 (Sydney: OTC Australia and Publimedia, 1992), 11
ikitravel contributors, “Cocos Islands,” Wikitravel: The Free Travel Guide, accessed June 9, 2013, http://wikitravel.org/en/Cocos_Islands.
Percy T. Chilvers, “Views in Cocos,” The Zodiac (1911): 312-316.
“How Houses Go Up In Cocos Island,” The Zodiac (1933): 269.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Only 108 square kilometers, Rodrigues Island was formed by volcanic eruptions 1.5 million years ago, making it both very small, and geologically, very young. For most of its short history, Rodrigues remained sheltered from extensive human intervention or cultivation. In the 17th and 18th centuries the Dutch and the French tried to settle and farm here, but their efforts were stymied by loneliness more so than the land itself. The French, who had brought African slaves from Mauritius, eventually gave up on farming and exhausted the island’s large tortoise population, using it to supply meat to passing ships. When the British took possession of Rodrigues in 1809, slavery was abolished and the freed slaves and colonists built a small but somewhat stable economy through tobacco and food exports. With commerce came communication, and in 1901 the British landed a telegraph cable here, stopping between Mauritius and the Cocos Islands.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1901-1950,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 25, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1901.htm.

Patrice Donzelot, “Internet: Europe Wants to Finance the Cable to Rodrigues,” Mauritius | Hi-Tech, http://business.mega.mu, accessed June 25, 2013, http://business.mega.mu/2013/05/07/internet-europe-wants-finance-cable-rodrigues/.
“The History of Rodrigues,” IOCP: The International Organization of Creole People, http://iocp.potomitan.info, accessed June 25, 2013, http://iocp.potomitan.info/rodrigues/rodrigues.htm.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Mauritius been a small but important stopping point for traffic across the Indian Ocean. Its visitors never merely pass through – they always leave something behind. In the 1600s, when the island became a waypoint for Dutch ships, generations of sailors and settlers left invasive species that devastated the local ecosystem. The flightless dodo bird and the domed giant tortoise were among the animals to disappear. When the French took possession of Mauritius in 1700s, they set up lucrative sugar plantations and brought in slaves from nearby Madagascar and Africa. And when the British colonized the island a century later, they replaced slavery with a system of indentured servitude, importing thousands of laborers from India. A telegraph cable was brought to the island shortly thereafter, and Mauritius became a stopping point for colonial dispatches between Europe, Africa and Asia. Although Mauritius has been an independent state since 1968, the former pathways of colonial powers have left their mark here: a diverse, multi-ethnic population, a connection point for transoceanic travelers, and a hub for communications infrastructure. Today, fiber-optic networks link to the edges of the island and data centers are nested in its interior.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Australian Cables,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 25, 2013, http://www.atlantic-cable.com/CableCos/Australia/.

Bill Glover, “The Evolution of Cable & Wireless, Part 3,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 25, 2013, http://www.atlantic-cable.com/CableCos/CandW/EATC/.

Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1901-1950,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 25, 2013, http://www.atlantic-cable.com/CableCos/Australia/.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: NTT,  PLDT,  Telekom Malaysia,  Starhub

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Landing at one of two designated sites on the northern and southern coasts of Changi, you make your way inland to a cluster of stations that form East Singapore’s primary cable hub. Today, the area is known for its major international airport complex, which includes a cactus garden, butterfly habitat, and what will soon be the world’s largest indoor waterfall. But this cutting-edge cable and aviation crossroads has a dark history. The British established a military base at Changi in the early 1900s when the peninsula was still mostly swampland and forests of tall “chengei” trees. During its occupation of Singapore in World War II, Japan used the compound to imprison thousands of captured Allied soldiers. (The prison was rebuilt in the 1990s and now has a death-row detention center). Even the northern beaches where cables come ashore, a popular spot for picnics and watersports, were the setting for a brutal 1942 massacre of Chinese Singaporeans thought to be anti-Japanese.

In 2012, Telekom Malysia (TM) contracted with the Japanese company NTT Communications to run two of the six optical fiber pairs of the Asia Submarine-cable Express (ASE) system connecting Malaysia, Singapore, Hong Kong, the Philippines, and Japan. The portion of the network owned by TM is branded Cahaya Malaysia (“cahaya” is the Indonesian word for “light”).

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: China Unicom,  Far Eastone Telecommunications,  Taiwan Mobile,  China Telecom,  Chunghwa Telecom,  China Mobile

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Though it was only activated in 2013, this is the first direct fiber-optic connection between Taiwan and Mainland China. Previously, signal traffic was routed through other hubs in regional networks. To some, the cable represents a major step toward greater economic cooperation across the Taiwan Strait.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Verizon Business,  AT&T,  KDDI,  Tata Communications,  China Telecom,  Chunghwa Telecom,  KT,  NTT,  Level 3,  SingTel,  Sprint,  Telekom Malaysia,  Telecom New Zealand,  Telstra,  PCCW,  LG Uplus,  Softbank Telecom,  Rostelecom,  SingTel Optus,  France Telecom

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: You have landed on the shores of Okinawa Island, just one island in an archipelago about 300 miles south of the rest of Japan and only 200 miles northeast of Taiwan. Geographically and politically separated from the other Japanese islands, Okinawa remained more or less self-governing until the Meiji Restoration, when it became a target for Japan’s expansionist aims. After winning the Sino-Japanese War in 1895, Japan immediately began laying cables to its colonial territories, including one that linked to Taiwan via Okinawa. For this endeavor, Japan even built its own cable ship, the Okinawa Maru. Following the massive destruction of World War II, Okinawa remained a cable hub, but the station was located far from the island's commercial center, perceived as more vulnerable to attack. Unlike the expansionist telegraph network, the coaxial and fiber-optic projects were collaborative international endeavors. Kokusai Denshin Denwa, Japan’s telecommunications company, partnered with American, Filipino, Chinese, and Korean companies to make Okinawa a stop on numerous transoceanic networks. Several cables continue to have a life even after they became obsolete, now carrying geophysical observations rather than telephone calls.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Tomishirominami High School Students, “The Sea in Gushikami,” Sea in Okinawa, accessed August 18, 2013, http://www.okiu.ac.jp/Language/contest/01/01/gushikami.htm.

“International Workshop on the Scientific Use of Submarine Cables,” Past Conferences – International Conferences with EM components, MTNet, accessed August 18, 2013, http://mtnet.dias.ie/conferences/1997/cables97.txt.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Completed in 2000, the consortium-owned China-U.S. Cable Network was the first direct cable route between the two countries. It consists of dual Pacific crossings, forming a ring structure with connections along the west coast of the U.S. and between several Southeast Asian hubs. Only a year after it entered service, however, the anchor of a fishing boat off Chongming Island disrupted much of the traffic between China and the U.S..

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Tonga Communications Corporation,  Government of Tonga

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Moving across this cable landing, you are careful not to sink into the ditches that dot the landscape. Trash clutters the beach, and nearby, shots are fired at the end of Rifle Range Road. The station at Vatuwaqa, like so many others, was built in a largely industrial, suburban area just north of Fiji's capital city, Suva. Yet unlike many contemporary cable stations, it is a place where people as well as signals come together. Men who work for Fiji's international telecommunications company are hanging out around the building. A dog lazily watches the front gate. Inside is a room constructed specifically for teleconferencing, where the company imagined new kinds of business relationships would emerge. As you pass through, you find a sense of camaraderie and hospitality among the cable workers. This is a place for meeting, for connecting, and for understanding cable history. In the courtyard, a monument commemorates the site's development as a satellite earth station, the landing point of the ANZCAN cable, and later, the Southern Cross system.

This cable, which links Tonga to Fiji and the entire Southern Cross trans-Pacific network, was completed in August 2013 with major funding from the Asian Development Bank and World Bank. Run by the government-owned Tonga Cable Limited, it is part of a larger effort to connect smaller island nations in the Pacific.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Telekom Malaysia,  AT&T,  Starhub,  PLDT,  Communications Authority of Thailand,  airtel (Bharti),  Telstra,  Telkom Indonesia,  BT,  Eastern Telecom,  PT Indonesia Satellite Corp.,  Telecom New Zealand,  Viettel Corporation,  Saigon Postal Corporation,  Vietnam Telecom International,  Brunei International Gateway,  BayanTel

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Landing at one of two designated sites on the northern and southern coasts of Changi, you make your way inland to a cluster of stations that form East Singapore’s primary cable hub. Today, the area is known for its major international airport complex, which includes a cactus garden, butterfly habitat, and what will soon be the world’s largest indoor waterfall. But this cutting-edge cable and aviation crossroads has a dark history. The British established a military base at Changi in the early 1900s when the peninsula was still mostly swampland and forests of tall “chengei” trees. During its occupation of Singapore in World War II, Japan used the compound to imprison thousands of captured Allied soldiers. (The prison was rebuilt in the 1990s and now has a death-row detention center.) Even the northern beaches where cables come ashore, a popular spot for picnics and watersports, were the setting for a brutal 1942 massacre of Chinese Singaporeans thought to be anti-Japanese.

Asia-America Gateway (AAG), opened in 2009, was the first high-bandwidth optical cable to provide a direct link between Southeast Asia and California (via the Philippines, Guam, and Hawai'i). Positioned further south than other trans-Pacific routes, AAG avoids the seismically active areas near Taiwan where earthquakes are known to cause cable disruptions.

Since the 1880s, Chikura has been known for precision exercises tied to the ocean. Every year, a knife ceremony is held at a local shrine dedicated to the gods of seasoning and culinary arts. Seven or eight men fillet and plate a whole carp using nothing but a twenty-inch blade and a pair of foot-long chopsticks, honoring the town’s legacy as a fishing community. In 1989, Chikura became a site of underwater cable innovation. The first fiber-optic line between the U.S. and Japan landed here, less than fifty miles from central Tokyo, followed by many other cables in the 1990s and 2000s. More recently, the town has become a surfing hub. Several professional competitions are held on Setohama Beach, where well-formed waves crash opposite the prominent cable station.

In the late 1980s Trans-Pacific Cable 3, a joint venture by AT&T, Japan’s KDD, and several other companies, was one of the first optical cables to cross the Pacific. With TPC-3, “fiber-optic technology now links Europe, North America, and Asia,” proclaimed the New York Times in April 1989. This offered several advantages: it was a second or two faster than satellite transmissions, as well as more secure, cheaper to operate, and less prone to interference than copper lines.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: AT&T

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: To build GOKI, AT&T commissioned two Japanese cable companies to pull up 800 miles of retired underwater networks, including portions of TPC-5. These fragments were then reengineered and combined with new fibers to create a much faster optical link between Japan and Guam.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Interchange

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: On a rainy November morning in 2013, a French cable team collaborated with a local construction crew to complete Vanuatu’s first underwater fiber-optic connection: a link to Fiji and the Southern Cross network. After surfacing on the black sand beaches of Mele Bay outside Port Vila, the cable runs inland to a modular station, assembled from five prefabricated units roughly the size of shipping containers. A high cinderblock wall surrounds the entire facility, blocking out potential intruders and making it less prominent than nearby medicinal gardens, coffee-roasting plants, and microbreweries. Through physically discrete, the station’s economic and cultural impact was by no means overlooked. Earlier that year, thousands gathered along the Port Vila waterfront to celebrate National Information and Communication Technologies Day and the cable’s impending arrival.
Owned by the Vanuatu-based telecom company Interchange and installed by France’s Alcatel-Lucent, this cable stretches over 700 miles between Port Vila and Suva, Fiji.

The price for Internet services has fallen significantly due to the cable's increase in network capacity.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Stretching a total of 24,000 miles between 39 landing sites, Southeast Asia-Middle East-Western Europe 3 (SeaMeWe-3) is more than twice as long as its intercontinental predecessor, SeaMeWe-2. The optical cable system was commissioned in 2000 by an international consortium of nearly 100 corporate investors.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The French company, La Societe Française des Télégraphes Sous-Marins, extended this cable from the Australian coast to New Caledonia in 1893, as part of a project to link France to its colonies.

On the shore at Mon Repos, a group of sea turtle hatchlings makes their way across the sandy beach and into the ocean. Long before this beach became a conservation park for the now endangered turtles, the site was a landing for a French telegraph cable. It was a short-lived system, connecting the nearby municipality of Bundaberg with the French colony of New Caledonia. At that time, Bundaberg and its environs were hardly developed. The area was populated by a small group of European timbergetters and farmers, and an established indigenous population of Kabi people, from whose language the city derives its name. A sawmill was built along the municipality’s river in 1868, drawing surveyors and settlers, and a sugar mill was built in 1882, around which a successful industry grew. This small, industrial, mostly British town had little interest in New Caledonia, a French colony known mostly for its political prisoners and fledgling mining industry.

In 1893, New Caledonia is changing. The prisoners have almost all left, and commerce is coming. A telegraph cable is being landed on New Caledonia’s soft shores. As you follow it inland, low brush and flowering bushes lead to dry meadows dotted with trees, providing little obstacle to signal traffic. Farther in, green and brown peaks soar upwards. Almost three decades earlier, nickel was discovered in these mountains, and since then the French have been mining the island. Despite their efforts at immigration, New Caledonia is now largely unpopulated by Europeans. Not long ago, the island was a French penal colony that held over 20,000 criminals and political prisoners. Many of them were Communards, punished for creating a self-governing socialist society in Paris. The cells emptied out when they were granted amnesty in 1879. With the discovery of nickel, this place began to serve a new purpose, and the French government hopes to establish itself in the South Pacific by making New Caledonia a hub. For now, there is but one route for telegraph signals: back and forth to Australia.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: ll Glover, “Australian Cables,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 22, 2013, http://www.atlantic-cable.com/CableCos/Australia/.
"Queensland-New Caledonia Cable, 1893-1923," National Archives of Australia, Brisbane Office, J2774 J2774/1, W11308.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: From the Batam cable station, you look out across rusty brown sand and a dark blue sea. Somewhere across that water is Singapore, where the far end of the cable has landed since 2006. The station shares the shore with many other industries. Silhouettes of cranes and oil rigs rise up against the landscape. Not much farther along the coast are ship-repair yards and ferry ports. Fiber-optic signals run underneath, supporting the large-scale transfer of goods and people to and from Singapore. Part of a free trade zone, the whole area is quite lassiez-faire. The city exerts relatively little control over the information, commerce, and people that stream in and out. This is in stark contrast to Indonesia's policy for cable ships: to repair systems in coastal seas, cable companies have to apply for permits, and might wait months before being granted access.

MIC-1 is only 70 km long, short enough to not need a repeater. Like many other cables that connect Singapore and Batam, it was designed to further development and attract Western investment in this international free trade zone.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Deep Water Bay cable station is situated on one of the most expensive properties in our undersea network. Overlooking a small bay on Hong Kong’s south shore, the station was built when there was little development in the area. Today, it is the oldest still operational station on the island and has been the connection point for numerous cables since the 1960s. In the intervening years, Hong Kong’s affluent residents migrated to the nearby hills and the area’s forest was replaced with mansions. Unlike the typical windowless structures that populate the cable system, Deep Water Bay’s postwar architecture offers a lookout onto the beaches and ocean below. Peering out of the station windows, you have a better view of the bay than Hong Kong’s richest man. There are few people here to enjoy it, however: since it opened, machines have replaced many of the workers.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: As you approach Colombo, Ceylon (present-day Sri Lanka) in 1903, your travel guide tells you: “its appearance is extremely picturesque: a fine undulating country, well wooded to the water’s edge and fringed by cocoa-nut trees; lofty verdant ranges tower in the distance, covered with groves of talipat and other palms.” Centrally positioned in the Indian Ocean, Colombo was a key trade port long before the colonial era. In the early 1500s, the Portuguese established a fort and trading post to capitalize on the island’s abundant cinnamon crops. After a brief Dutch occupation, Colombo was ceded to the British and became the capital of British Ceylon. To facilitate faster communication to London, a submarine cable was brought to the island via the Middle East in 1913, connecting to a new Central Telegraph Office in a three-story wood building near the harbor. Messages could now travel between the two cities in as little as thirty minutes, a savings of nearly four hours compared to older land-based routes through India. Today, messages transit in only milliseconds from five cable systems that land in the Colombo area.

When it was finished in December 2005, the consortium-owned Southeast Asia-Middle East-Western Europe 4 cable provided both additional bandwidth and greater redundancy along the bulk of the previous-generation SeaMeWe-3 line between the Mediterranean and Singapore. SeaMeWe-3, however, extends significantly further to points in China, Japan, Australia, the U.K., and Germany, among others.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: China-Japan Fiber Optic Sea Cable (C-J FOSC)

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: C-J FOSC, laid in 1993 for $70 million dollars, was the first fiber-optic undersea system connecting mainland China to the rest of the world. From its landing point in Miyazaki, Japan, it linked outward to much of Southeast Asia. Although this gave China connectivity, it made the nation highly dependent on one Japanese hub.

From a mostly undeveloped beach several miles north of Miyazaki, you follow a dirt path inland until it opens onto a single-lane road. In the distance, a ringed communications tower is visible above the treetops. Homing in on this beacon, you reach a windowless building surrounded on all sides by a barbed-wire fence. Three majestic palm trees and a plaque bearing the logo of Japanese telecom company KDDI mark the entrance, while farmland and greenhouses occupy the surrounding plots. In 1977, the first telephone cable arrived from Okinawa, where a trans-Pacific link to the U.S. had recently been completed. Optical cables followed in the 1990s, but more recent connections have overlooked Miyazaki in favor of the cluster of hubs along the east coast of Honshu Island.

Built in the 1970s, the Nanhui station was the first landing site for international coaxial cables in China. Early signals surfaced on the muddy shores of Nanhui district, then mostly farmland, roughly thirty miles southeast of central Shanghai. Now the area is almost unrecognizable, transformed by rapid industrialization that has displaced many of its former inhabitants. Large-scale development projects have even altered the local geography, continuing a process begun millennia ago when Nanhui was formed by silt deposited at the mouth of the Yangtze River. New cables pass by a huge artificial island that contains the recently constructed Shanghai deep-water container port, linked to the mainland by a twenty-mile bridge. And just east of the station, an entire city for 800,000 is being built from scratch on land reclaimed from Hangzhou Bay.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1903, the Eastern Extension, Australasia and China Telegraph Company received a contract from the Dutch East Indies Government to lay a cable between Balikpapan and Menado with a stop in Kwandang. Covering roughly 650 miles, the cable was deployed by sister ships Restorer and Patrol, launched from England that year and sold for scrap to the Japanese only a decade later.

A 1903 guidebook describes the bay of Kwandang as “beautiful and picturesque” but also “abandoned” and “densely covered with vegetation.” There is “scarcely a house or sign of cultivation . . . to be seen anywhere in the midst of the primeval wood.” The town is located inland from the port and is largely invisible through the foliage. Although secluded, “the neatness of the roads and houses proves that Kwandang is not a self-governed country, but under Dutch Government.” The Portuguese arrived in the 1500s and built a stone fort to defend the region from pirates. A century later, the Dutch took possession of the island-filled bay, one of the best natural harbors in northern Sulawesi. In 1903, they linked it by submarine cable to Balikpapan and Menado. Despite clear signs of development, however, Kwandang remained a wild place. A gang of pirates besieged the colony in the late 1800s until Dutch ships finally “came to the rescue from Ternate.”

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Before Hong Kong was handed back to China, one author observed that it was a “center of espionage, a hive of spies,” with up to 5,000 intelligence agents seeking information for countries around the world. In 1977, the British GCHQ built a satellite base at Chung Hom Kok, on Hong Kong’s less populated southern coast. For over a decade, the satellite base, code-named “Project Kittiwake,” was a center for monitoring Chinese communications and nuclear tests. It was scanned communications about events such as the Tiananmen Square massacre in 1989 and the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991. When Hong Kong was transferred back to China, Project Kittiwake was moved and the site razed, leaving little for the Chinese to see. At the turn of the century, the Chinese government invested in Chung Hom Kok’s external communications – it was designated a “telecentre” for the development of satellite and submarine connections. Today a new undersea cable station, poised on the edge of a hill and overlooking small fishing boats that dot the waters, still monitors traffic. Rather than intercepting signals sent through the air, communications are now filtered before they are allowed to enter mainland China.

The consortium-owned Southeast Asia Japan Cable (SJC) runs from Singapore to Japan, with branch connections to Thailand, Brunei, the Philippines, Hong Kong, and China. Intense demand along the communication route prompted capacity upgrades less than a year after it was built in 2013.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Waves crash up against a thick seawall that spans the coast of Toucheng. Much of the shore here in northeast Taiwan is comprised of sand rock, eroded by ocean waves and monsoon winds. Some locals think these spectacular rock formations resemble tofu. Yet the erosion here is not entirely natural. The presence of manmade structures on 56% of Taiwan’s coast, this seawall included, has sped up the disappearance of its beaches. These structures interrupt the flow of sand, causing it to accumulate on one side and to quickly erode on the other. The nearby Toucheng beach, which once stretched for two kilometers, is now severely diminished, and the coast has retreated up to 100 meters inland. This seawall keeps the shoreline intact for both waves and cable stations, but provides an additional challenge for cable laying. Companies have to bore a hole through the thick walls in order to thread their networks through.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1942, diversion of the 1905 Guam - Yap - Menado cable

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1942, Japan diverted a German cable (originally laid in 1905 between Menado, Yap, and Guam) to Palau, where it had military installations and regional government headquarters from 1914 to 1944.

A century ago, Yap was a Pacific communications hub, the junction point of three cables linking Guam, Shanghai, and Manado. Colonized by Germany, it was a critical node in their vast cable network of over 18,000 miles. Yap also formed an important bridge between America and China. From Guam, the United States relied on the German-Netherlands network to connect to Shanghai. During World War I, the Japanese seized the island and Yap became not only a “cable threat,” but a threat to the sea route between the U.S. and the Philippines. After the war, the possession of Yap, its cables, and its coaling station was the subject of a dispute between the United States and Japan. Japan claimed that the island had been designated to her under a Mandate of the League of Nations. The United States sought to put Yap under “International supervision” as an international cable station, rather than under control of a single nation. After a year of deadlock, the United States and Japan came to an agreement that split the network, and subsequently eliminated all cable links. Today, Yap remains without cable systems and without high-speed Internet infrastructure, linked only via wireless technologies. A single satellite station carries all of Yap’s Internet traffic out of the country.

Traveling across clear blue waters and through mushroom-shaped rock islands, you reach the shores of Palau. Beneath a pristine landscape often imaged in tourism magazines lies a modern history of struggles between nations. Although inhabited for millennia without interference, Palau’s strategic position in the North Pacific drew competing territorial claims in the late 1800s from Britain, Spain, and Germany. After a period of Spanish rule, the fertile islands were sold to the Germans who began exploiting their natural resources. Japan annexed Palau in 1914, established a regional government headquarters, promoted large-scale immigration, and built fish canneries and coconut processing plants. The town of Koror, Palau’s capital, was once known as “Little Tokyo,” a nod to the strong Japanese presence in this period. During World War II, a German telegraph cable was redirected to Palau to strengthen communication links to Japan. And in 1944, Japanese and American forces clashed in the months-long Battle of Peleliu with heavy casualties on both sides. Although Palau finally became an independent state in 1994, in many ways it remains dependent on the infrastructure and currency of other nations.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Gordon L. Rottman, World War II Pacific Island Guide: A Geo-Military Study. Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 2002.
