http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: As you emerge from the ocean in Sainte-Marie you hear the roar of airplanes above you and the murmur of French conversation all around. Although it is located off the coast of Madagascar, Réunion is one of the oversea departments of France and is therefore part of the same political, financial and social systems as the mainland. Even with less than a million inhabitants, this small island is linked by two different cable networks, giving its Internet a security and speed largely unknown to other remote locales. Accordingly, Réunion has been marketed as a gateway for Western entrepreneurs to develop business around the Indian Ocean without having to deal with the infrastructural disparities or cultural differences they might find on the African continent. From its inception as a colonial trading port to today, Réunion has been a waypoint for the movement of Western goods, information, and influence into Africa and India. From here, you might move via cable networks to the nearby island of Mauritius, or all the way across the Indian Ocean.

The South Africa-Far East (SAFE) cable system, built in 2002 by a U.S. company, traverses the Indian Ocean on a path similar to the one taken by Portuguese explorers in the fifteenth century. By joining the SAT-3/WASC cable at Melkbosstrand, South Africa, SAFE provides a direct optical fiber link between Western Europe and Malaysia.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Kyushu Electric Power,  KT,  Softbank Telecom,  NTT

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Kitakyushu has been a networked industrial center in southern Japan for more than a century. Beginning in the early 1900s, Japan’s largest steel mill refined iron ore from Korea and China into metal for shipbuilding and the rapidly expanding railroad system. This made Kitakyushu a target during the Second World War, including the original target for the bomb later dropped on Nagasaki. Today, the city is home to Kyushu’s largest ferry port and second-largest train station, as well as a factory that produces more than three thousand miles of submarine cable each year. It’s also the birthplace of celebrated Japanese crime novelist Seichō Matsumoto. In his 1957 bestseller Points and Lines, police investigators discover two bodies on a secluded beach and use railway schedules to locate the suspects in time and space.

Fukuoka has been an exchange point between Japan and the rest of Asia for millennia. In the year 57, a Han Dynasty emperor bestowed a gold seal on the King of Na (present day Fukuoka). Over the following centuries, the city’s proximity to Korea and China facilitated international trade as well as the flow of Buddhism and agricultural techniques into Japan. But this proximity also made it a target: Fukuoka was attacked by Mongol fleets in the 1200s, only to be saved by well-timed typhoons or “kamikazes” (Japanese for “divine wind”). Communication technologies only reinforced these ancient economic, cultural, and military connections. Telegraph cables linked the Kyushu region with Korea beginning in the 1880s, radiotelephone was introduced in the 1920s, and the arrival of a submarine cable in 1937 provided long-distance telephone service between Japan, Korea, and China for the first time.

This Korean city has long been a hub for Japanese connections. In the nineteenth century it served as Japanese merchants’ primary access point to Asian trade networks. When it opened, Busan’s Japanese-run telegraph station became an equally important gateway. It handled all Korean telegraph traffic until an overland link to Seoul was completed in 1888, and it allowed Japanese-language telegrams to leave the country for the first time. Cable traffic spiked from a few thousand messages sent between the two countries in 1884 to some 430,000 — the vast majority in Japanese. In 1931, Busan was the site of Japanese experiments for another communications revolution: the use of undersea cables for voice transmission. Today, the city’s two cable stations, which provide a major gateway to the Internet, are finally operated by Korean companies. Yet the country faces another challenge at its shores – from local aquaculture rather than foreign powers. Dense seaweed forests immediately off Busan’s coast twist around ropes bordering the cable’s path. Harvesting the seaweed, fishermen come dangerously close to the country’s international communications lines. Whenever cable companies land a new system, they have to be careful not to disturb the fragile seaweed’s growth. Each cable must be carefully placed in a “mattress” before it is lowered down into the crop.

A partnership between Korea Telecom, Japan Telecom, NTT Communications, and the Kyushu Electric Power Company, this cable entered service ahead of the 2002 World Cup, co-hosted by the two countries. From Busan, the system makes two, 150-mile journeys across the Korea Strait to Kyushu, a trade route that dates back to the 14th century.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: One of the first fiber cable systems laid in the Pacific, Hawaii-4 was also one of the shortest lived. It went out of service after a mere 15 years, not because it broke, but rather due to economic obsolescence.

Heading inland to the Makaha cable station, you surface in a parking lot, in a manhole barely visible under the dirt. Along the beaches to the south of this town reside hundreds of houseless people. O‘ahu’s west shore is home to one of the state’s largest native communities and largest homeless population. In Makaha alone, 32% of its residents live in poverty. Yet, the west shore is also a transit point for a large percentage of the state’s international signal traffic. Since the 1960s, almost all of the island’s coaxial and fiber-optic cables have terminated at three cable stations along this short 30-kilometer stretch. The seemingly divergent histories of telecommunications success and economic deprivation in the area are intertwined, and linked to the area's long-standing military occupation. Weapons testing sites and military installations, such as the Lualualei Naval Reservation and the Schofield Barracks, displaced residents from the west shore’s inland valleys. At the same time, the U.S. military was once one of the biggest customers of the cable networks, giving them both an economic boost and a layer of protection when they were set up during the Cold War.

To get to California’s oldest still-operational cable landing point, established in Point Arena in 1957, you would have to travel over a hundred miles north from San Francisco along narrow wooded roads. The cable station is positioned on a bluff overlooking the Pacific. Across the road from the station, families picnic at a campsite. Cows graze in a nearby pasture. Between the station and the beach, a sign restricts access to a “sensitive habitat area.” At first glance these environments, and the signs indicating environmental preservation, appear to secure both wildlife and cables, protecting infrastructure from perception and potential tampering. But such environments also pose a problem to those laying undersea cables. At this station, cable builders had to undergo extra permitting,  and ultimately delay, to ensure that they did not endanger the Point Arena mountain beaver.

When it opened in 1991, the North Pacific Cable was the highest-capacity system to link Japan and North America. “This pioneering effort helps usher in what futurists . . . call the fibersphere,” declared the president of Pacific Telecom, the cable’s U.S. sponsor. The following year, Tokyo Broadcasting System sent high-definition television signals between Miura and Pacific City to demonstrate the “Advantages of terrestrial fiber transmission” over satellite, including “high bandwidth, high reliability and less delay.”

Forming the southern edge of Tokyo Bay, the Izu Peninsula received its first domestic underwater cables in the 1970s. In the 1990s, international systems joined Miura to the rest of Asia, Europe, and the U.S., echoing a long history of maritime connections. In 1600, English navigator William Adams arrived in Japan and became a government advisor on shipbuilding and foreign affairs. Renamed “the pilot of Miura,” Adams settled near present-day Yokosuka in eastern Miura, now a major Japanese and U.S. naval base. More than four hundred years later, Minoru Saito became the oldest person to sail non-stop around the world at age 71, beginning and ending in Miura. The 234-day solo journey was his seventh circumnavigation.

In 1991, North Pacific Cable built a brand new station on the remote Oregon coast. Established far from the AT&T landing in Bandon, this building pioneered cable landing in northern Oregon, now a critical gateway for Internet traffic entering and leaving the country. Even though it paved the way for development, North Pacific Cable was eventually made obsolete by these newer links, and with this, the station was shut down. It was not until years afterward that Tillamook Lightwave purchased the station in order to expand regional access to the network. Part of the station was leased to the University of Washington for their Regional Scale Nodes project, an ocean cable system that lets scientists observe deep-sea life forms and processes. A building constructed merely to funnel signals through the area now links the many populations, human and non-human, on the Oregon coast.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/rightsHolder.value: Reliance Globalcom

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Appropriately named Keoje, Korean for “great crossing,” this island is the landing site of several international submarine cable networks, though it is still smaller than the hub in nearby Pusan. As you come ashore through clear waters, the sound you hear is not heavy rainfall but the pebbles on Hakdong beach tumbling in the surf. Named after a crane (“hak” in Korean), this wing-shaped beach sits in a valley covered by flowering camellia plants, sheltered from the industrial shipyards and granite mines further north. Eschewing the discrete architecture of many contemporary cable facilities, the Korea Telecom landing station calls attention to itself with an ornate design. Decorative columns and topiaries line the station’s brick and glass entryway, which faces away from Hakdong’s beachfront promenade.

Entering service in 1997, the FLAG (Fiber-Optic Link Around the Globe) Europe-Asia cable system connects the United Kingdom with Japan via more than a dozen landing sites. The cable, now operated by an Indian telecom, was the subject of a 1996 Wired magazine article by cyberpunk author Neal Stephenson in which he traveled to “six countries and four continents trying to get a grip on this longest, fastest, mother of all wires.”

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Ninomiya was the first landing site for trans-Pacific coaxial cables in Japan, built in 1964 to receive TPC-1 from Guam. As one of the oldest still-operational stations in the country, it served as a training ground for Japanese cable workers, some of whom later became leaders in the industry. For a period of time, it was also a hotbed of submarine cable research, where new cable technologies were designed and developed. Unlike many modern stations, however, it is located in a central residential area populated by commuters to Odawara and Tokyo-Yokohama. Even though Ninomiya is linked to these urban areas, the greenery of Azumayama Park makes them easy to leave behind. Climb up the hill behind the station and you will enter the park, passing several shrines and temples on your journey to the summit. Dense woods open onto a grassy plain with commanding views of Sagami Bay and Mount Fuji. Artist Hokusai Katsushika included this vista in his series of woodblock prints of Fuji as seen from different Japanese towns, drawing Ninomiya into an early-nineteenth-century visual network.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: North of the original telegraph termination point at Weltevreden lies Jakarta’s post-independence cable hub. The area’s swamplands were once the home to the Dutch Fort Zouteland (“saline land”), and during the Japanese occupation of Jakarta during World War II, Ancol was the site of mass executions and burials. In films of the 60s and 70s, Ancol was portrayed as a mysterious and ghostly place. After Indonesia gained independence, the country’s founding President envisioned the transformation of Jakarta into a great international city, and coastal Ancol as a space for recreation, a “showcase of the nation.” His dreams were not recognized for decades, and even then, they came at a price. Developers dredged the nearby coast, destroying a beach that had made it accessible to Indonesia’s underclass, and converted the marshland for recreation facilities. Today, the theme park Ancol Dreamland, Sea World of Indonesia, resort hotels, and beaches are all accessible only with a fee.
